description: From German Adenin, from Ancient Greek ἀδήν (adḗn, “gland”); surface analysis, aden- +‎ -ine. It was named in 1885 by the German biochemist Albrecht Kossel, in reference to the pancreas (a specific gland) from which Kossel's sample had been extracted.

entries.meaning: (biochemistry, genetics) A base, C5H5N5, found in certain glands and tissues, which pairs with thymine in DNA and uracil in RNA.
examples: Coordinate terms: cytosine, guanine, thymine, uracil
